bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Hanover County was formed from New Kent County in 1720.

Most county court records, particularly deeds, wills, and marriage records, were destroyed by fire in Richmond on 3 April 1865, where they had been moved for safekeeping during the Civil War. The circuit court records were not moved to Richmond and were relatively unscathed. Consequently, there is a strong run of common law papers and chancery papers after 1831 that were generated by the circuit superior court of law and chancery and its successor, the circuit court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Hanover County (Va.) plats and surveys, 1769-1875, n.d., found in this collection include a plat and survey (1769) of 181 acres done on behalf of Captain William Clark; a plat and survey (1814) of 131 1/2 acres done on behalf of Benjamin Hooper; a plat and survey (n.d.) of 42 acres done on behalf of Samuel Perrin; a plat of 252 acres known as Wheaten's tract; a plat (1875) of land owned by Thomas H. Fox in Ashland, Virginia, on both sides of the Richmond, Fredericksburg, and Potomac Railroad divided into lots; map (n.d.) of the eastern half of Hanover County showing the location of communities, railroad lines, and creeks.
